instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used on the quantitative detection of low temperature stress in tea plants?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used on the quantitative detection of low temperature stress in tea plants were successive projections algorithm (SPA), competitive adaptive reweighted sampling (CARS), and uninformative variable elimination (UVE).

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the modeling on the quantitative detection of low temperature stress in tea plants, and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the modeling effect of the different machine learning methods on the quantitative detection of low temperature stress in tea plants was the coefficient of determination (R-2), root mean square error of prediction (RMSEP), and residual prediction deviation (RPD). These metrics were used to assess the accuracy and predictive power of the models.

The results showed that the best prediction model for the seven indicators of low temperature stress in tea plants was the LTRI-UVE-CNN model, with an R-2 value of 0.890, RMSEP of 0.325, and RPD of 2.904. 

Based on these metrics, it can be concluded that the LTRI-UVE-CNN model had a strong modeling effect and was able to accurately predict the degree of low temperature stress in tea plants.

instruction: Can the LTRI-UVE-CNN model, used in the related study for quantitative detection of low temperature stress in tea plants, be considered a more efficient and less laborious method compared to traditional approaches?
